explosives.rationale: Containing no chemical groups with explosive properties

flammable_gases.rationale: Classified as "liquid" according to GHS definition

oxidizing_gases.rationale: Classified as "liquid" according to GHS definition

gases_under_pressure.rationale: Classified as "liquid" according to GHS definition

flammable_solids.rationale: Classified as "liquid" according to GHS definition

self_reactive_substances.rationale: Containing no chemical groups with explosive or self-reactive properties

pyrophoric_liquids.rationale: Not pyrophoric when in contact with air at ordinary temperatures (flash point: 275degC (IUCLID, 2000)).

pyrophoric_solids.rationale: Classified as "liquid" according to GHS definition

self_heating_substances.rationale: Test methods applicable to liquid substances are not available.

substances_mixtures_emit_flammable_gas_i.hazard_name: Substances and mixtures which, in contact with water, emit flammable gases
substances_mixtures_emit_flammable_gas_i.rationale: Containing no metals or metalloids (B, Si, P, Ge, As, Se, Sn, Sb, Te, Bi, Po, At)

oxidizing_liquids.rationale: Organic compounds containing no oxygen, fluorine or chlorine

oxidizing_solids.rationale: Classified as "liquid" according to GHS definition

acute_toxicity_oral.rationale: Based on the rat LD50 (oral route) value of 550mg/kg (SIDS (2005)).

acute_toxicity_inhalation_gas.rationale: Due to the fact that the substance is "liquid" according to the GHS definition and inhalation of its gas is not expected.

acute_toxicity_inhalation_vapor.rationale: Based on the rat LC50 value of 0.003ppm (4 hours), calculated from the testing data of rat LC50 (inhalation of vapour) of 0.40mg/L, 0.42mg/L and 0.44mg/L (SIDS (2005)), was lower than 90% of the saturated vapour concentration (80ppm) under a saturated vapour pressure of 0.08kPa (20degC) (SIDS (2005)), the substance was considered as "vapour containing substantially no mist" and was classified based on standard values expressed in ppm.

skin_corrosion_irritation.hazard_statement: Causes severe skin burns and eye damage
skin_corrosion_irritation.rationale: Based on the description in the report on rabbit skin irritation tests (SIDS (2005)): "Corrosive." Although classified into Category 1A-1C, the substance should be placed in Category 1A from the viewpoint of safety if further subclassification is needed.

serious_eye_damage_irritation.rationale: Based on the description in the report on rabbit eye irritation tests (SIDS (2005)): "Corrosive."

germ_cell_mutagenicity.rationale: Based on the description in the report on a skin painting test and a Maximization test in guinea pigs (SIDS (2005)): "Not sensitizing."

carcinogenicity.rationale: Based on the absence of data on in vivo mutagenicity tests and no positive data on in vitro mutagenicity tests (several indices), described in SIDS (2005).

systemic_toxicity_single_exposure.rationale: Histopathological changes, such as seminiferous tubular atrophy, were observed at doses producing general toxicity in repeated dose toxicity studies and teratogenicity studies with rats (SIDS (2005)). However, SIDS attributes these changes to the indirect effects of general toxicity of a severe degree.

systemic_toxicity_repeat_exposure.hazard_name: Specific target organ toxicity - Single exposure
systemic_toxicity_repeat_exposure.classification: Category 2 (nervous system, heart, kidney, respiratory system)
systemic_toxicity_repeat_exposure.hazard_statement: May cause damage to organs (nervous system, heart, kidney, respiratory system)
systemic_toxicity_repeat_exposure.rationale: Based on the evidence from animal studies including "sedation, laboured breathing, dyspnea, spasm, arrhythmia, cardiac fibrillation, proteinuria, kidney damage" (BUA 143 (1996)), "corrosive to the respiratory tract; inhalation of aerosols may result in pulmonary edema" (ICSC (J) (2002)). The effects on experimental animals were observed at dosing levels within the guidance value ranges for Category 1. However, the referenced studies are assigned a priority rating of 2, the effects are classified into Category 2.

aspiration_hazard.hazard_name: Specific target organ toxicity - Repeated exposure
aspiration_hazard.classification: Category 1 (kidney), Category 2 (respiratory system, liver, blood system, adrenal gland, heart)
aspiration_hazard.hazard_statement: Cause damage to organs through prolonged or repeated exposure (kidney) May cause damage to organs through prolonged or repeated exposure (respiratory system, liver, blood system, adrenal gland, heart)
aspiration_hazard.rationale: Based on the evidence from animal studies including "vacuolar degeneration of the nasal mucosa and olfactory epithelium, elevated GOT/GPT, decreased hemoglobin level/mean corpuscular hemoglobin concentration (MCHC), and mild renal tubular nephrosis" (SIDS (2001)), "histological changes in the liver, red blood cell, white blood cell, kidneys, adrenal and heart" (SIDS (2001)). The effects on experimental animals were observed at dosing levels within the guidance value ranges for Category 1 (kidneys) and Category 2 (respiratory organs, liver, blood system, adrenal, heart).

acute_aquatic_toxicity.rationale: It was classified into Category 2 from 48 hours EC50=4.6mg/L of the crustacea (Daphnia magna) (MOE eco-toxicity tests of chemicals, 2000).

chronic_aquatic_toxicity.hazard_statement: Toxic to aquatic life with long lasting effects
chronic_aquatic_toxicity.rationale: Although acute toxicity was Category 2 and the bio-accumulation potential was low (BCF=6(Existing Chemical Safety Inspections Data)), since there was no rapidly degrading (the decomposition by BOD: 0%(Existing Chemical Safety Inspections Data)), it was classified into Category 2.
